title: Habakkuk Chapter 2 Quiz - Multi-Level
description: An enhanced quiz on Habakkuk chapter 2 with Easy, Medium, Hard, and Theological levels. Each level has 15 carefully crafted questions. Choose your difficulty and dive in!

easy.title: Habakkuk Chapter 2 Quiz - Easy Level
easy.description: Perfect for beginners! Test your basic knowledge of Habakkuk Chapter 2.

questions.question: Where does Habakkuk say he will stand to watch and listen in Habakkuk 2:1?
questions.correctAnswer: Upon the tower
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 2:1 says, 'I will stand upon my watch, and set me upon the tower...'

questions.question: What did the LORD command Habakkuk to do with the vision in Habakkuk 2:2?
questions.correctAnswer: Write the vision
questions.explanation: In Habakkuk 2:2, the LORD says, 'Write the vision, and make it plain upon tables...'

questions.question: According to Habakkuk 2:3, how should one respond if the vision seems delayed?
questions.correctAnswer: Wait for it
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 2:3 states, '...though it tarry, wait for it; because it will surely come...'

questions.question: Who shall live by faith according to Habakkuk 2:4?
questions.correctAnswer: The just
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 2:4 says, '...but the just shall live by his faith.'

questions.question: What causes the proud man to transgress in Habakkuk 2:5?
questions.correctAnswer: Wine
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 2:5 states, 'because he transgresseth by wine, he is a proud man...'

questions.question: What will the nations do to the one who increases that which is not his, according to Habakkuk 2:6?
options: Take up a parable against him
questions.correctAnswer: Take up a parable against him
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 2:6 says, 'Shall not all these take up a parable against him...?'

questions.question: What will bite and vex the proud man suddenly, as mentioned in Habakkuk 2:7?
questions.correctAnswer: Those who rise up
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 2:7 says, 'Shall they not rise up suddenly that shall bite thee...?'

questions.question: Why will the proud man be spoiled by others according to Habakkuk 2:8?
questions.correctAnswer: Because he spoils many nations
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 2:8 states, 'Because thou hast spoiled many nations... all the remnant of the people shall spoil thee.'

questions.question: What does Habakkuk 2:9 warn about coveting?
questions.correctAnswer: An evil covetousness
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 2:9 says, 'Woe to him that coveteth an evil covetousness to his house...'

questions.question: What will the stone and timber do according to Habakkuk 2:11?
questions.correctAnswer: Cry out and answer
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 2:11 states, 'For the stone shall cry out of the wall, and the beam out of the timber shall answer it.'

questions.question: True or False: Habakkuk 2:14 says the earth will be filled with the knowledge of the glory of the LORD.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 2:14 says, 'For the earth shall be filled with the knowledge of the glory of the LORD...'

questions.question: True or False: Habakkuk 2:15 condemns giving a neighbor drink to make them drunken and expose their nakedness.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 2:15 states, 'Woe unto him that giveth his neighbour drink... that thou mayest look on their nakedness!'

questions.question: True or False: Habakkuk 2:20 declares that the LORD is not in His holy temple.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 2:20 says, 'But the LORD is in his holy temple...'

questions.question: Complete this verse from Habakkuk 2:4: 'Behold, his soul which is lifted up is not upright in him: but the ______ shall live by his faith.'
questions.correctAnswer: just
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 2:4 says, '...but the just shall live by his faith.'

questions.question: Complete this verse from Habakkuk 2:2: 'Write the vision, and make it plain upon ______, that he may run that readeth it.'
questions.correctAnswer: tables
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 2:2 states, 'Write the vision, and make it plain upon tables...'

medium.title: Habakkuk Chapter 2 Quiz - Medium Level
medium.description: Ready for more? Apply biblical truths from Habakkuk Chapter 2 to real-life situations.

questions.question: A fellow believer is going through a trial and asks you for counsel. Based on Habakkuk 2, what biblical truth would you share about living by faith?
options: The just shall live by his faith
We must build cities with justice
questions.correctAnswer: The just shall live by his faith
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 2:4 states that 'the just shall live by his faith,' teaching us that faith is essential for enduring trials. This is supported by the call to wait patiently for God's vision (2:3), and the assurance that God is in His holy temple (2:20).

questions.question: How does Habakkuk 2 instruct us to respond when receiving a vision or divine message?
options: Write the vision and make it plain so it can be understood
Keep the vision secret and mysterious
Only share the vision with the elders
Wait quietly without recording the vision
questions.correctAnswer: Write the vision and make it plain so it can be understood
questions.explanation: According to Habakkuk 2:2, the LORD commands to 'Write the vision, and make it plain upon tables, that he may run that readeth it,' encouraging clear communication of God's word for understanding and obedience. This supports faithfulness and preparation (2:1, 2:3).

questions.question: A believer struggles with impatience waiting for God's promises. What encouragement does Habakkuk 2 provide about timing?
options: Though it tarry, wait for it; because it will surely come
God's promises come immediately without delay
We must force God's timing by praying more
Promises depend on human effort to succeed
questions.correctAnswer: Though it tarry, wait for it; because it will surely come
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 2:3 teaches that although the vision may delay, it will surely come at the appointed time, encouraging believers to be patient and trust God's timing, supported by faith (2:4) and God's sovereignty (2:20).

questions.question: How does Habakkuk 2 warn against pride and greed in everyday life?
options: Pride leads to destruction and insatiable desire
Pride is a sign of spiritual strength
questions.correctAnswer: Pride leads to destruction and insatiable desire
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 2:5 describes the proud man as one who transgresses by wine and enlarges his desire as hell, never satisfied, illustrating the destructive nature of pride and greed. This is echoed in verses 6-9 warning about consequences of covetousness and oppression.

questions.question: A believer asks how to maintain integrity in their work and dealings. What guidance does Habakkuk 2 offer?
options: Do not increase that which is not yours and avoid injustice
Gain wealth by any means necessary
Ignore the needs of others to succeed
questions.correctAnswer: Do not increase that which is not yours and avoid injustice
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 2:6 warns against increasing that which is not yours and loading oneself with 'thick clay,' symbolizing dishonest gain. This teaches the importance of honesty and justice in daily life, supported by 2:12-13 condemning building by bloodshed and iniquity.

questions.question: True or False: According to Habakkuk 2, God will bring judgment on those who oppress others and shed innocent blood.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 2:8 clearly states that because a man has spoiled many nations and shed blood, the remnant will spoil him, indicating God's judgment on oppressors, supported by 2:12 and 2:17.

questions.question: What does Habakkuk 2 say about the knowledge of God's glory in relation to the earth?
options: The earth shall be filled with the knowledge of the glory of the LORD as the waters cover the sea
Only a few will know God's glory
God's glory is hidden from the earth
The knowledge of God will fade over time
questions.correctAnswer: The earth shall be filled with the knowledge of the glory of the LORD as the waters cover the sea
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 2:14 promises that God's glory will fill the earth like waters cover the sea, encouraging believers to live in hope and share God's glory through evangelism and faithful living, supported by 2:2 and 2:20.

questions.question: A believer is tempted to cause others to stumble through bad influence. What warning does Habakkuk 2 give?
options: Woe to him who gives his neighbor drink to look upon their nakedness
Encourage others to enjoy freely without restraint
It is harmless to influence others negatively
Helping others indulge is a sign of love
questions.correctAnswer: Woe to him who gives his neighbor drink to look upon their nakedness
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 2:15 condemns those who cause others to sin by making them drunken, illustrating the importance of guarding others and ourselves from temptation, consistent with teachings on love and responsibility in community (2:20).

questions.question: True or False: Habakkuk 2 teaches that idols have power and can teach us truth.
questions.correctAnswer: False
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 2:18-19 questions the profit and power of idols, calling them dumb and without breath, emphasizing that only the LORD is worthy of reverence (2:20), teaching us to trust God alone.

questions.question: How does Habakkuk 2 describe the outcome for those who build their cities by injustice and bloodshed?
options: They bring woe upon themselves and labor in vain
God will bless their efforts abundantly
questions.correctAnswer: They bring woe upon themselves and labor in vain
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 2:12-13 warn that building a city by blood and iniquity leads to woe and laboring in vain, teaching the importance of integrity and righteousness in all undertakings, supported by 2:10 and 2:6.

questions.question: A believer is struggling with shame and guilt for past sins. What hope does Habakkuk 2 offer concerning God's justice?
options: The cup of the LORD's right hand will be turned to bring shame to the wicked
God ignores the sins of the proud
Shame is permanent with no hope
questions.correctAnswer: The cup of the LORD's right hand will be turned to bring shame to the wicked
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 2:16 teaches that the LORD's judgment will bring shame on the proud and wicked, assuring believers that God's justice prevails and encouraging repentance and faith, supported by 2:4, 2:20.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Habakkuk 2:20 says, 'But the LORD is in his holy temple: let all the earth keep ______ before him.'
questions.correctAnswer: silence
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 2:20 declares that the LORD is in His holy temple and calls for all the earth to keep silence before Him, emphasizing reverence and humility in God's presence, consistent with the call to faith and trust (2:4, 2:3).

questions.question: What does Habakkuk 2 teach about the fate of those who oppress and spoil nations?
options: They will be spoiled by the remnant of the people
They will be blessed for their strength
questions.correctAnswer: They will be spoiled by the remnant of the people
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 2:8 states that those who spoil many nations will themselves be spoiled by the remnant, teaching that injustice will be judged and encouraging believers to trust God's righteous judgment (2:6, 2:12).

questions.question: How does Habakkuk 2 illustrate God's awareness of injustice through everyday life imagery?
options: The stone shall cry out of the wall, and the beam out of the timber shall answer it
The wind will carry away injustice silently
The sky will darken without notice
The earth will shake without a word
questions.correctAnswer: The stone shall cry out of the wall, and the beam out of the timber shall answer it
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 2:11 uses vivid imagery of stones and beams crying out to show that God is aware of injustice even in construction, reminding believers that God sees all and calls for integrity and justice, as seen in 2:12-13.

questions.question: A Christian parent is teaching their child about humility. How does Habakkuk 2:4 provide a foundation for this lesson?
options: His soul which is lifted up is not upright, but the just shall live by faith
Pride is a sign of strength and favor
Humility is only for the weak
Faith is unnecessary if you are humble
questions.correctAnswer: His soul which is lifted up is not upright, but the just shall live by faith
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 2:4 contrasts pride with uprightness and emphasizes living by faith, teaching humility as essential for a righteous life, which is vital for parenting with biblical wisdom (2:3, 2:20).

hard.title: Habakkuk Chapter 2 Quiz - Hard Level
hard.description: Challenge yourself with deep analysis and cross-biblical connections from Habakkuk Chapter 2.

questions.question: In Habakkuk 2:2, God commands Habakkuk to write the vision. What is the purpose of making the vision 'plain upon tables'?
options: So that the one who reads it may run with it
So that the priests may interpret it
So that kings may keep it secret
So that it may be hidden from enemies
questions.correctAnswer: So that the one who reads it may run with it
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 2:2 states that the vision should be made plain upon tables so that the one who reads it may run, emphasizing clarity and urgency in the communication.

questions.question: The phrase 'the just shall live by his faith' in Habakkuk 2:4 is famously quoted in which New Testament book?
questions.correctAnswer: Romans
questions.explanation: Paul quotes Habakkuk 2:4 in Romans 1:17 to support the doctrine of justification by faith, showing the continuity between the Old and New Testaments.

questions.question: In Habakkuk 2:5, the proud man is compared to which of the following?
questions.correctAnswer: Hell
questions.explanation: Verse 5 uses the imagery of hell to describe the insatiable desire of the proud man, highlighting the destructive nature of pride.

questions.question: According to Habakkuk 2:6, what kind of literary device is used when the nations take up a parable and a taunting proverb against the oppressor?
questions.correctAnswer: A proverb and parable
questions.explanation: The verse explicitly mentions a parable and a taunting proverb, which are forms of poetic and rhetorical devices used for reproach.

questions.question: Fill in the blank: Habakkuk 2:7 warns that those who have been wronged 'shall rise up suddenly that shall ______ thee.'
questions.correctAnswer: bite
questions.explanation: The verse states that those wronged will 'rise up suddenly that shall bite thee,' indicating sudden retribution.

questions.question: What reason does Habakkuk 2:8 give for the remnant of the people spoiling the oppressor?
options: Because of men's blood and violence in the land
questions.correctAnswer: Because of men's blood and violence in the land
questions.explanation: Verse 8 says the oppressor will be spoiled because of the bloodshed and violence perpetrated against many nations and cities.

questions.question: Habakkuk 2:9 pronounces woe on him who covets evil to his house. What is the intended outcome for this person?
options: To be delivered from the power of evil
To be blessed by the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: To be delivered from the power of evil
questions.explanation: The verse indicates the person's covetousness aims at deliverance from evil power, but it is pronounced woe because of the evil intent.

questions.question: According to Habakkuk 2:11, what will the stone and timber do as a form of witness?
questions.correctAnswer: Cry out and answer
questions.explanation: Verse 11 personifies the building materials to emphasize that injustice in building will not go unnoticed; the stone and timber will 'cry out' and 'answer'.

questions.question: What is the key theme expressed in Habakkuk 2:14 about the earth?
options: The earth shall be filled with the knowledge of the glory of the LORD
The earth shall be cursed for its wickedness
The earth shall be destroyed by fire
The earth shall be divided among nations
questions.correctAnswer: The earth shall be filled with the knowledge of the glory of the LORD
questions.explanation: Verse 14 proclaims the ultimate outcome of God's plan: universal knowledge of His glory, symbolizing restoration and divine sovereignty.

questions.question: True or False: Habakkuk 2:15 condemns those who give their neighbors drink to make them drunk and look upon their nakedness.
questions.correctAnswer: True
questions.explanation: Verse 15 pronounces woe on anyone who causes their neighbor to become drunk for malicious purposes, highlighting moral corruption.

questions.question: In Habakkuk 2:18, the prophet questions the profit of what kind of image?
questions.correctAnswer: A graven image
questions.explanation: The verse critiques the making and trusting in graven images, which are lifeless idols, emphasizing futility.

questions.question: What is the significance of the phrase 'let all the earth keep silence before him' in Habakkuk 2:20 in the context of ancient Near Eastern worship?
options: It calls for reverent silence acknowledging God's ultimate authority
It demands silence to avoid disturbing pagan rituals
It instructs people to stop all work during festivals
It suggests that God is silent and inactive
questions.correctAnswer: It calls for reverent silence acknowledging God's ultimate authority
questions.explanation: Verse 20 contrasts the silent reverence due to the LORD in His holy temple with the noise of idolatry, affirming God's sovereign presence.

questions.question: Habakkuk 2:12 pronounces woe upon him who builds a town with what method?
questions.correctAnswer: With blood
questions.explanation: The verse condemns those who establish cities through violent and unjust means, indicating moral corruption in leadership.

questions.question: Which ancient Near Eastern cultural practice is implicitly criticized in Habakkuk 2:19 when the prophet mocks the command to 'Awake' to wood and stone?
questions.correctAnswer: Idolatry and animism
questions.explanation: The verse mocks the practice of worshipping lifeless idols, characteristic of ancient Near Eastern religions, exposing their impotence.

questions.question: Habakkuk 2:3 mentions the vision is for an appointed time and will not tarry. How does this relate to the biblical concept of divine timing seen elsewhere?
options: It echoes Ecclesiastes 3:1 about a time for everything
It contradicts the idea of sudden judgment in Amos
It relates only to Habakkuk's personal prophecy
It denies the possibility of future fulfillment
questions.correctAnswer: It echoes Ecclesiastes 3:1 about a time for everything
questions.explanation: The verse aligns with the biblical theme that God's plans unfold in their proper time, paralleling Ecclesiastes 3:1's teaching on seasons and divine purpose.

theological.title: Habakkuk Chapter 2 Quiz - Theological Level
theological.description: Deep biblical theology from Habakkuk Chapter 2 that unites all believers. Explore foundational truths about God, creation, and humanity.

questions.question: According to Habakkuk 2:4, what is the condition of the just person in contrast to the proud soul?
options: The just shall live by his faith
The just shall live by his works
The just shall live by the law
The just shall live by sacrifice
questions.correctAnswer: The just shall live by his faith
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 2:4 explicitly states that 'the just shall live by his faith,' emphasizing faith as the means of life for the righteous. This is consistent with Romans 1:17, Galatians 3:11, Hebrews 10:38, and also echoes God's covenantal faithfulness in Genesis 15:6.

questions.question: What instruction does the LORD give Habakkuk regarding the vision in Habakkuk 2:2?
options: Write the vision and make it plain
Hide the vision until the appointed time
Tell no one until the vision is fulfilled
questions.correctAnswer: Write the vision and make it plain
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 2:2 commands to 'Write the vision, and make it plain upon tables, that he may run that readeth it,' signifying the clarity and urgency of God's revelation. This principle is echoed in Exodus 17:14, Isaiah 30:8, and the New Testament emphasis on clear proclamation in 2 Timothy 3:16.

questions.question: What does Habakkuk 2:3 teach about the timing and certainty of God's vision?
options: Though it tarry, wait for it; it will surely come
It will come quickly and without delay
The vision is uncertain and may not come
The vision is hidden and only for the elect
questions.correctAnswer: Though it tarry, wait for it; it will surely come
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 2:3 assures that although the vision may delay, it will surely come at the appointed time, affirming God's sovereign timing. This truth aligns with Psalm 37:7, Ecclesiastes 3:1, 2 Peter 3:9, and Romans 8:25 concerning patient waiting on God's promises.

questions.question: Habakkuk 2:5 describes the character of a proud man who transgresses by wine. Which of the following best summarizes his nature?
options: He is insatiable and gathers nations unto himself
He is humble and seeks peace
He is patient and trusts in the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: He is insatiable and gathers nations unto himself
questions.explanation: Verse 5 depicts the proud man as one who 'enlargeth his desire as hell,' insatiable and greedy, gathering nations to himself. This mirrors descriptions in Proverbs 21:4, Isaiah 5:22, Luke 12:15, and James 4:6 about pride and covetousness leading to destruction.

questions.question: What consequence does Habakkuk 2:6 warn against for one who 'increaseth that which is not his'?
options: Woe and a taunting proverb shall be taken up against him
He will be exalted and blessed
He will inherit the earth peacefully
He will be forgotten and ignored
questions.correctAnswer: Woe and a taunting proverb shall be taken up against him
questions.explanation: Habakkuk 2:6 pronounces woe and taunting proverbs against those who unjustly increase their possessions, reflecting God's judgment on greed. This is consistent with Proverbs 28:25, Ezekiel 16:49, Luke 16:14-15, and 1 Timothy 6:9-10 which warn against pride and covetousness.

questions.question: In Habakkuk 2:8, why will the remnant of the people spoil the oppressor?
options: Because he has spoiled many nations and shed blood
Because he showed kindness to the poor
Because he built a strong city
questions.correctAnswer: Because he has spoiled many nations and shed blood
questions.explanation: Verse 8 states that the oppressor will be spoiled because of his violence and shedding of blood. This reflects God's justice against violence and oppression, echoed in Exodus 22:22-24, Psalm 94:1-3, Isaiah 1:17-23, and Luke 18:7.

questions.question: Habakkuk 2:11 says, 'For the stone shall cry out of the wall, and the beam out of the timber shall answer it.' What theological truth does this convey?
options: The judgment against injustice is so certain that even inanimate objects will testify
Buildings are sacred and cannot be harmed
The stones and timber are idols to be worshiped
The city will be eternally protected
questions.correctAnswer: The judgment against injustice is so certain that even inanimate objects will testify
questions.explanation: This verse metaphorically portrays God's judgment as inevitable and manifest, even stones and timber bear witness. This is parallel to Deuteronomy 19:15, Luke 19:40, Revelation 6:13, and Psalm 96:10 affirming creation's testimony to God's justice.

questions.question: What is the ultimate purpose of the labor and toil mentioned in Habakkuk 2:13, according to the LORD of hosts?
options: The people labor in vain and wear themselves out for vanity
They will build a lasting kingdom
questions.correctAnswer: The people labor in vain and wear themselves out for vanity
questions.explanation: Verse 13 declares that people labor and weary themselves for vanity under God's sovereign control, highlighting the futility of rebellion. This is consistent with Ecclesiastes 1:3, Isaiah 40:29-31, Matthew 6:19-21, and Romans 8:20-21 on the vanity of earthly toil apart from God.

questions.question: In Habakkuk 2:14, what will fill the earth according to the vision?
options: The knowledge of the glory of the LORD
questions.correctAnswer: The knowledge of the glory of the LORD
questions.explanation: Verse 14 promises that the earth will be filled with the knowledge of God's glory as waters cover the sea, a prophetic vision of universal recognition of God. This is echoed in Isaiah 11:9, Habakkuk 2:14, Habakkuk 2:14, and Revelation 21:23, emphasizing God's ultimate reign.

questions.question: Habakkuk 2:15 pronounces woe on those who give their neighbor drink to see their nakedness. What sin does this condemn?
options: Exploiting others through drunkenness to shame them
questions.correctAnswer: Exploiting others through drunkenness to shame them
questions.explanation: The verse condemns the sin of causing one's neighbor to become drunk to shame or exploit them, revealing moral corruption. This aligns with Proverbs 23:29-35, Isaiah 5:11, Ephesians 5:18, and 1 Thessalonians 5:22 warning against drunkenness and exploitation.

questions.question: What does Habakkuk 2:18 question regarding idols and their makers?
options: What profiteth the graven image when the maker trusts in his dumb idol?
How do idols speak to the people?
questions.correctAnswer: What profiteth the graven image when the maker trusts in his dumb idol?
questions.explanation: Verse 18 challenges the futility and deception in trusting created idols, which have no life or power. This is consistent with Isaiah 44:9-20, Psalm 115:4-8, Jeremiah 10:5, and Acts 17:29-31 teaching the folly of idolatry.

questions.question: In Habakkuk 2:20, what is the appropriate response of the earth before the LORD in His holy temple?
options: Let all the earth keep silence before him
Let the earth rejoice and sing loudly
Let the earth shake with fear
Let the earth rebel against Him
questions.correctAnswer: Let all the earth keep silence before him
questions.explanation: The verse calls for reverent silence before the LORD's holy presence, emphasizing His sovereign majesty. This reverence is echoed in Psalm 46:10, Exodus 20:18-19, Isaiah 6:1-5, and Habakkuk 2:20 itself, reinforcing God's holiness.

questions.question: Habakkuk 2:9 pronounces woe on him who covets evil covetousness to his house. What does this desire aim to achieve?
options: To set his nest on high and be delivered from evil
To share wealth with the poor
To build a temple for God
questions.correctAnswer: To set his nest on high and be delivered from evil
questions.explanation: The verse condemns selfish ambition to secure personal safety through ill-gotten gains. This contrasts with biblical teaching on trusting God rather than riches for safety, as in Proverbs 11:28, Jeremiah 17:5, Matthew 6:19-21, and 1 Timothy 6:17.

questions.question: What does Habakkuk 2:16 predict will happen to the one filled with shame for glory?
options: The cup of the LORD's right hand will be turned to him, bringing shameful spewing
He will be honored and glorified
He will be forgotten by all
questions.correctAnswer: The cup of the LORD's right hand will be turned to him, bringing shameful spewing
questions.explanation: Verse 16 describes divine judgment as a cup of wrath causing shame and disgrace, consistent with God's righteous punishment in Psalm 75:8, Jeremiah 25:15-16, Revelation 14:10, and Nahum 1:6.

questions.question: According to Habakkuk 2:7, what will happen to the oppressor who gathers others to himself?
options: Those who bite and vex him will rise up suddenly, making him a booty
He will be blessed with peace
He will find refuge among his allies
questions.correctAnswer: Those who bite and vex him will rise up suddenly, making him a booty
questions.explanation: The verse predicts sudden retribution against the oppressor, highlighting God's justice and the instability of evil alliances. This aligns with Proverbs 16:18, Isaiah 10:5-19, Luke 1:52, and Romans 12:19.
